summary: This is the Jeffrey E. Epstein 2012 Trust Agreement, dated October 24, 2012, outlining the management and disposition of Epstein's assets during his life and after his death. It names trustees, details specific bequests to associates and staff, forgives loans, and establishes trusts for properties and a primary beneficiary, with Eva Dubin as a key contingent beneficiary.

persons.name: Jeffrey E. Epstein
persons.context: The creator of the trust, who assigns his property to the trustees and reserves significant powers to amend, revoke, or withdraw from the trust during his lifetime.

persons.name: Darren K. Indyke
persons.context: Named as one of the three initial trustees of the trust, responsible for administering the trust assets. He is also a beneficiary, receiving a $5 million bequest and Epstein's interest in KCAC, LLC.

Epstein names Dubin as the primary contingent beneficiary of the residuary trust and several property trusts, indicating she is a significant beneficiary of his estate.

events.title: Execution of Epstein 2012 Trust
events.description: Jeffrey E. Epstein executes the 'The Jeffrey E. Epstein 2012 Trust' agreement, establishing a trust to manage his assets during his life and after his death.

locations: 9 East 71st Street, New York, New York 10021
Little St. James Island, United States Virgin Islands
49 Zorro Ranch Road, Stanley, New Mexico 87056
358 El Brillo Way, Palm Beach, Florida
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein established a complex trust in October 2012, naming Darren K. Indyke, James E. Staley, and Andrew Farkas as trustees with broad powers.

The trust document lists specific bequests of $5 million each to Ghislaine Maxwell, Karyna Shuliak, Jean Luc Brunel, and Darren Indyke (who also receives Epstein's interest in KCAC, LLC), among others.
Epstein forgave loans made to several individuals, including Jean Luc Brunel, Mark Epstein, and staff members Luciano and Rosalyn Fontanilla.

The trust outlines plans for separate 'residence trusts' for an unnamed primary beneficiary for properties in Paris, New York City, Little St. James Island, New Mexico, and Palm Beach, with millions allocated for operating expenses.
Eva Dubin (also referred to as Eva Andersson Dubin) is named as the primary contingent beneficiary of the residuary trust and the property trusts if the primary beneficiary does not survive.
